programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE
programme.desc: NHK NEWSLINE brings you up to date with the latest from Japan, Asia and around the world. Our team covers breaking news and major developments, with trusted anchors to tie it all together.

programme.title: Today's Close-Up
programme.sub-title: Braking Point: The Science of Safe Driving as We Age
programme.desc: For many elderly Japanese, a car provides vital access to daily necessities and essential services. While many remain confident in the safety of their driving, their families often become concerned with the decline in their cognitive and physical functions. Should they keep their driver's license or give it up? It's a question given added urgency by a spate of accidents involving older drivers. Researchers are hoping to provide an answer with a new body of data-driven work that has given rise to the idea of the "driving lifespan" - the years during which someone can continue to safely operate a vehicle. We take a look at what the latest science shows and ask an expert what people can do to extend their driving lifespan as much as possible. Guest: Shimada Hiroyuki (Director, National Center for Geriatrics and Gerontology)

programme.title: NEWSROOM TOKYO
programme.desc: NEWSROOM TOKYO dives deeper into the day's news with insight and analysis, from the perspective of Japan and the rest of Asia. We put a spotlight on what you need to know to understand the issues.

programme.title: Direct Talk
programme.sub-title: The Heart of the Sutra Remixed
programme.desc: Akasaka Yogetsu, a priest with an international following, is known for combining beatboxing with Buddhist mantras. He talks about Zen philosophy and the spirit of "living in the here and now."

programme.title: RAMEN JAPAN 5min.
programme.desc: In Yamagata, a city that eats more ramen than any other in Japan, uncover the mysteries behind the unusual local ramen!

programme.title: Framing Everyday Moments
programme.desc: Flowers burst into full bloom and sprouting buds reach towards the sunlight, their movements following the rhythm of nature. Created by photographer Washiduka Toshiko.

programme.title: Ukiyoe EDO-LIFE
programme.sub-title: A Night of Fashion and Fireworks
programme.desc: For a time during the Edo period, fireworks lit up the skies practically every night in the summer. It was a chance for women to dress up and let loose ... and grab the attention of male suitors. *"Women Watching Fireworks at Sumida River" (1795-96) by Kitagawa Utamaro

programme.title: Hometown Stories
programme.desc: In the city of Sakata in northeastern Japan, maiko have entertained people for centuries. Now, a master of the art is helping younger women follow in her path, and gain confidence with every step.

programme.title: Satoyama Kitchen Diary
programme.desc: Hi! It's me, Tama! Today, we harvest buckwheat. And by "we," I mean, Grandpa Makoto and Grandma Nobuko will. Good luck, you two! Off you go!

programme.title: Japanology Plus
programme.desc: *First broadcast on April 13, 2023. In Japan, interest in camping is booming. Popular choices these days include women-only camping and solo camping. Some prefer glamping, where you don't have to set up your own tent. Camping has also been drawing attention as a good way to prepare for disaster. Peter Barakan visits a campsite with an outdoor expert to get the latest information, and to find out more about why so many people are going camping these days. We also see some Japanese preferences in equipment.

programme.title: Today's Close-Up
programme.sub-title: The 'Land of Gold' Returns: Eyes Turn to Japan Amid Record Prices
programme.desc: Gold prices continue to soar worldwide. Amid this unprecedented boom, international operators are conducting exploratory mining around closed gold mines in Japan. Meanwhile, competition is intensifying to extract gold from used electronic devices. While efforts to acquire gold are accelerating in some countries around the world, problems such as the spread of illegal mining are also arising in Africa. What will this new gold rush bring to the world, and to us? Guests: Negishi Shoko (Associate Professor, Doshisha University), Kawamura Youhei (Professor, Hokkaido University)

programme.title: Activate Your Japanese!
programme.desc: Drama "Xuan Tackles Japan!" It is the day of the summer festival, and they find out that the MC for the karaoke contest is unable to come. Tadokoro asks Xuan to stand in, along with Sasaki. The man who was supposed to be the MC explains what they should do and in what order over the phone, but Sasaki is left confused. Xuan tries to clarify his explanation but is unsuccessful. Yansu appears and gives her advice. How can she make it easier to understand what they should be doing? "Onomatopoeia" -Share Feelings- Texture of Food 2 "Welcome to My Japan!" focuses on the life of NAGATA Marie from the Philippines, who runs a driver's school in Shizuoka Prefecture!

programme.sub-title: Introducing Multilingual Services at the Embassy of Bangladesh
programme.desc: With multilingual services, NHK WORLD-JAPAN helps foreign residents with disaster prevention and daily life. A presentation introducing these services was given at the Embassy of Bangladesh, in Tokyo.

programme.title: Direct Talk
programme.desc: In 2024, a team led by Saito Kentaro won the bronze trophy as well as a special prize at the prestigious Montreal International Fireworks Competition. He talks about what fireworks mean to him.

programme.title: Passing the Torch of Peace
programme.sub-title: Friendship Forged by Shared Atomic Bomb Past
programme.desc: Ari Beser's grandfather served on the planes that dropped atomic bombs on Hiroshima and Nagasaki. Harada Kosuzu's grandfather survived both. Now they are fighting for a world without nuclear weapons. NHK Hiroshima's website (in Japanese) https://www.nhk.or.jp/hiroshima/hibaku/80/

programme.title: National Parks of Japan
programme.desc: Keramashoto National Park comprises more than 30 islands and is known for its highly transparent waters called the Kerama Blue and its coral population. The coral, which supports a thriving marine ecosystem, is protected from predators by local volunteers. The region also boasts a unique culture from its past as the Ryukyu Kingdom.

programme.title: Ukiyoe EDO-LIFE
programme.desc: We visit an Edo-style open-air teahouse, where the townspeople enjoyed refreshments, conversation ... and the company of exotic birds. For them, these outings were about more than a good time.

programme.title: Today's Close-Up
programme.sub-title: Braking Point: The Science of Safe Driving as We Age

programme.title: Seasoning the Seasons
programme.desc: Nara, one of Japan's ancient capitals, is home to spirits and demons. Due to its long history, the city has seen its fair share of wars and plagues. For local people the essence of difficulty and disaster is captured in demon form. But demons, with their huge flaming torches, can also help see in the blessings of spring. Demons and fire visit the people of Nara as they pray for a bountiful spring season.

programme.title: Journeys in Japan
programme.sub-title: Okinawa: Whispers of the Ryukyu Kingdom
programme.desc: Across the Ryukyu Islands, you can find elevated sites surrounded by stone walls. The walls protected gusuku or castles built between the 14th and the 15th centuries. Unlike the castles in mainland Japan that emerged in the Sengoku period (15th to 16th centuries), gusuku were also sacred places of community rituals and festivals. Photographer Alfie Goodrich feels the history of Okinawa through exploring these precious ruins.

programme.title: Medical Frontiers
programme.sub-title: The Impact of Biologics on Inflammatory Diseases
programme.desc: Biologic drugs, made mainly from antibodies, have transformed the approach to treating chronic inflammatory diseases such as asthma and rheumatoid arthritis. We explore their mechanisms and potential.

programme.title: NHK NEWS 7
programme.desc: News 7 is NHK's flagship domestic evening news program, bringing you the latest from our Tokyo studio. It's presented with English audio on NHK World for our international viewers

programme.title: Journeys in Japan
programme.sub-title: Okinawa: Whispers of the Ryukyu Kingdom
programme.desc: Across the Ryukyu Islands, you can find elevated sites surrounded by stone walls. The walls protected gusuku or castles built between the 14th and the 15th centuries. Unlike the castles in mainland Japan that emerged in the Sengoku period (15th to 16th centuries), gusuku were also sacred places of community rituals and festivals. Photographer Alfie Goodrich feels the history of Okinawa through exploring these precious ruins.

programme.title: NEWSROOM TOKYO

programme.title: Direct Talk
programme.sub-title: Capturing Movement and Sense of Touch
programme.desc: Mizushiri Yoriko won the Silver Bear in the short film competition at the 2025 Berlin International Film Festival. She talks about her passion for creating animations that evoke a sense of touch.

programme.title: Passing the Torch of Peace
programme.desc: The key to achieving peace is feeling the pain of others. It's an idea Hayashida Mitsuhiro picked up from hibakusha in his native Nagasaki, and one he tries to teach young visitors to his city.

programme.title: A Culture Built with Wood
programme.desc: The Hida region in Gifu Prefecture has some of the country's most extensive broadleaf forests. Here, local artisans with sophisticated woodworking techniques are referred to as "Hida's Master Craftsmen," a title that has been respected for 1,300 years. Their skills are showcased in the floats of the Takayama Autumn Festival, ranked among the 3 most beautiful festivals in Japan. These floats are crafted using Japanese wood joinery techniques and do not use a single nail. Join us as we examine the craftsmanship that interlocks with the Hida region.

programme.title: Ukiyoe EDO-LIFE
programme.desc: We attend a New Year's concert at a samurai residence, where a master koto player delights a crowd of gorgeously dressed celebrity-types. Lounging in the best seat in the house ... is no ordinary V.I.P.

programme.title: Today's Close-Up
programme.sub-title: The 'Land of Gold' Returns: Eyes Turn to Japan Amid Record Prices
programme.desc: Gold prices continue to soar worldwide. Amid this unprecedented boom, international operators are conducting exploratory mining around closed gold mines in Japan. Meanwhile, competition is intensifying to extract gold from used electronic devices. While efforts to acquire gold are accelerating in some countries around the world, problems such as the spread of illegal mining are also arising in Africa. What will this new gold rush bring to the world, and to us? Guests: Negishi Shoko (Associate Professor, Doshisha University), Kawamura Youhei (Professor, Hokkaido University)

programme.title: The Seasons of Yamato
programme.desc: Hannyaji Temple is known as "Kosumosudera (cosmos flower temple)." During wintertime, the main flowers are daffodils. They bloom as if they are competing around the stone statues of Buddhists, which were dedicated in appreciation for curing diseases. Are those flowers praising the virtues of the Buddha or showing off their beauty? The 13-story stone pagoda, which has stood there since the Kamakura period, is towering against the crisp blue winter sky. *According to the 24 Solar Terms of Reiwa 4 (2022), Shoukan is from January 5 to 20.

programme.title: Little Charo
programme.desc: This program is an animation series about a Japanese dog, Charo. He meets and is helped by many mythical creatures of Northern Japan as he searches for eight star talismans.

programme.title: Japanology Plus mini
programme.desc: The cardboard beds used during the Tokyo 2020 Olympic and Paralympic Games captured global attention. That was just one example of the many innovative ways in which Japan has made use of this humble material. Modern cardboard can be insect-repellent, waterproof or strong enough to carry a piano. It's also used in emergency goods such as rooms and toilets. In fact, people in Japan use roughly 150 new cardboard boxes a year. In a 5-minute digest, we examine a broad range of cardboard products.

programme.title: A Cat's-Eye View of Japan
programme.desc: A scallop fisherman's cat, Miya, keeps watch while her owner is at sea. Once he's back, Miya's ready to cuddle. Meanwhile, a cat in Hachinohe City sits on her owner's newspaper to get his attention.

programme.title: The World Heritage Sites in Japan
programme.sub-title: Triangular Roofs Bring People Together: Historic Villages of Shirakawa-go and Gokayama
programme.desc: Shirakawa-go in Gifu Prefecture is one of Japan's snowiest regions. It's famous for its traditional thatched-roof Gassho-style homes. The triangular roofs distribute the weight of heavy snow evenly, and the steep slopes allow residents to remove snow with little effort. Hearth fires provide heat that dries out thatch and soot that blackens pillars and beams. These homes have lasted for so long because they are still inhabited. The cooperative bond between residents is a key part of life here and is essential when rethatching these homes. Come and visit a mountain village that appears to be frozen in time.

programme.title: Time-lapse Japan
programme.desc: Okinawa Prefecture is a group of subtropical islands in the far south of Japan. We examine its past and present, with footage from time-lapse creator Shimizu Daisuke. This time: The Holiest Place.

programme.desc: An ekiben with specialty yuzu from Umaji Village is available beside a tourist railway in Kochi. Yuzu once saved the village from extinction. This is the story of people behind yuzu fragrant ekiben.

programme.title: Core Kyoto
programme.sub-title: Core Kyoto mini Furniture Restoration: Giving Life to Treasured Heirlooms
programme.desc: The furniture cleaning industry is sustained by many Kyotoites' desire to cherish and hand down their belongings over generations. The techniques used to restore paulownia-wood chests, which are used for kimono, to their former glory has been handed down over 3 generations. Discover Kyotoites' respect for history and continuity.

programme.title: Easy Japanese for Work
programme.sub-title: #2 How to politely ask someone to repeat something
programme.desc: This episode is about asking someone to repeat something. Putri-san, from Indonesia, learned Japanese in university. She has been working in the real estate field for 4 years in Japan. Putri-san works entirely in Japanese, but finds some katakana words difficult. By role-playing and receiving guidance from experts, she'll learn how to politely ask someone to repeat something.

programme.title: Zero Waste Life
programme.desc: Artisan Matoba Kensho restores traditional dolls. Beyond cleaning, he repairs damage to faces. Well-cared-for dolls can last 100 years, so he hopes people bring them to him, and never discard them.

programme.title: Together with the Camphor Trees: KUSUNOKI -5,000 Souls Sing a Prayer for Peace
programme.sub-title: 5,000 Souls Sing a Prayer for Peace
programme.desc: In August, Fukuyama Masaharu sang "KUSUNOKI" with a choir of 5,000 people, sending a prayer for peace from Nagasaki to the world. We look at the song's meaning and how it has touched people's hearts.

programme.title: One in Every Japanese
programme.desc: 1 in 1,000 Japanese have experience as a lay judge in court cases. We witness a networking event for former lay judges, where they discuss unique experiences. What does it feel like to judge others?

programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE
programme.desc: NHK NEWSLINE brings you up to date with the latest from Japan, Asia and around the world. Our team covers breaking news and major developments, with trusted anchors to tie it all together.

programme.title: ANIME MANGA EXPLOSION
programme.desc: In this episode, we explore the craft of anime sound. Voice actor Otsuka Akio, who has performed in over 400 anime titles, recreates recording sessions from My Hero Academia and BLEACH: Thousand-Year Blood War, revealing the techniques behind iconic lines. We also go behind the scenes at the music recording session for the new anime Star Wars: Visions Volume 3 "The Duel: Payback," where composer Inai Keiji crafts a dramatic score that brings the visuals to life.

programme.title: The New Adventures of Rockie and Her Friends
programme.desc: Rockie is paired up with Juras for a play to put on during the school arts day. When Juras fails to learn the script, Rockie shows frustration, and Juras stops coming to school. Educational theme: Justice and fairness.

programme.title: Texico
programme.desc: Learn the principles of programming without even touching a computer in this new-style education program. Unique animated characters assist in the fun and lucid introduction of 5 core programming processes: analysis, combination, generalization, abstraction and simulation.

programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE
programme.desc: NHK NEWSLINE brings you up to date with the latest from Japan, Asia and around the world. Our team covers breaking news and major developments, with trusted anchors to tie it all together.

programme.title: J-MELO
programme.desc: *This program was first broadcast on August 3, 2025. Join May J. for great Japanese music! This week: cool R&B-rooted J-pop from girl duo Natsudaidai; and EDM-influenced rock from THE SIXTH LIE. Both acts are in the J-MELO studio to chat and perform. On Demand until January 25, 2026

programme.title: Little Charo
programme.desc: This program is an animation series about a Japanese dog, Charo. He meets and is helped by many mythical creatures of Northern Japan as he searches for eight star talismans.

programme.title: Japanology Plus mini
programme.desc: The cardboard beds used during the Tokyo 2020 Olympic and Paralympic Games captured global attention. That was just one example of the many innovative ways in which Japan has made use of this humble material. Modern cardboard can be insect-repellent, waterproof or strong enough to carry a piano. It's also used in emergency goods such as rooms and toilets. In fact, people in Japan use roughly 150 new cardboard boxes a year. In a 5-minute digest, we examine a broad range of cardboard products.

programme.title: A Cat's-Eye View of Japan
programme.desc: A scallop fisherman's cat, Miya, keeps watch while her owner is at sea. Once he's back, Miya's ready to cuddle. Meanwhile, a cat in Hachinohe City sits on her owner's newspaper to get his attention.

programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE
programme.desc: NHK NEWSLINE brings you up to date with the latest from Japan, Asia and around the world. Our team covers breaking news and major developments, with trusted anchors to tie it all together.

programme.title: EKIBEN JAPAN
programme.sub-title: Carrying On the Aroma of Yuzu
programme.desc: An ekiben with specialty yuzu from Umaji Village is available beside a tourist railway in Kochi. Yuzu once saved the village from extinction. This is the story of people behind yuzu fragrant ekiben.

programme.title: Core Kyoto
programme.sub-title: Core Kyoto mini Furniture Restoration: Giving Life to Treasured Heirlooms
programme.desc: The furniture cleaning industry is sustained by many Kyotoites' desire to cherish and hand down their belongings over generations. The techniques used to restore paulownia-wood chests, which are used for kimono, to their former glory has been handed down over 3 generations. Discover Kyotoites' respect for history and continuity.

programme.title: Easy Japanese for Work
programme.sub-title: #2 How to politely ask someone to repeat something
programme.desc: This episode is about asking someone to repeat something. Putri-san, from Indonesia, learned Japanese in university. She has been working in the real estate field for 4 years in Japan. Putri-san works entirely in Japanese, but finds some katakana words difficult. By role-playing and receiving guidance from experts, she'll learn how to politely ask someone to repeat something.

programme.title: Zero Waste Life
programme.desc: Artisan Matoba Kensho restores traditional dolls. Beyond cleaning, he repairs damage to faces. Well-cared-for dolls can last 100 years, so he hopes people bring them to him, and never discard them.

programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE
programme.desc: NHK NEWSLINE brings you up to date with the latest from Japan, Asia and around the world. Our team covers breaking news and major developments, with trusted anchors to tie it all together.

programme.title: The World Heritage Sites in Japan
programme.sub-title: Triangular Roofs Bring People Together: Historic Villages of Shirakawa-go and Gokayama
programme.desc: Shirakawa-go in Gifu Prefecture is one of Japan's snowiest regions. It's famous for its traditional thatched-roof Gassho-style homes. The triangular roofs distribute the weight of heavy snow evenly, and the steep slopes allow residents to remove snow with little effort. Hearth fires provide heat that dries out thatch and soot that blackens pillars and beams. These homes have lasted for so long because they are still inhabited. The cooperative bond between residents is a key part of life here and is essential when rethatching these homes. Come and visit a mountain village that appears to be frozen in time.

programme.title: Time-lapse Japan
programme.desc: Okinawa Prefecture is a group of subtropical islands in the far south of Japan. We examine its past and present, with footage from time-lapse creator Shimizu Daisuke. This time: The Holiest Place.

programme.title: GRAND SUMO Highlights
programme.desc: NHK WORLD-JAPAN presents a sumo highlights program for fans around the globe. Today the show features all top-division bouts from January 18, Day 8 of the Grand Sumo Tournament in Tokyo.

programme.title: Sumopedia
programme.desc: Sumopedia enriches your sumo experience with information on the techniques, traditions and famous wrestlers of the past. The rules may be simple but there is a lot more to sumo than meets the eye.

programme.title: Chatroom Japan
programme.desc: Maminata Ouandaogo's passion for African hairstyles has helped hundreds in Japan with their natural hair. But outside her salon, she says social pressure keeps some people from embracing it.

programme.title: IMPACTS: Climates Change the World
programme.sub-title: Extreme Snowfall: An Effect of Global Warming
programme.desc: Reductions in Arctic sea ice caused by global warming have ironically led to record-breaking Northern Hemisphere snowfalls and frequent winter storms. What mechanism is at work?

programme.desc: Tottori Prefecture / Hishikawa Seiichi (Video and craft artist) Dyeing firms make fishing flags with vivid, hand-drawn designs that carry the feelings of both fishermen and people sending them gifts.

programme.title: Where We Call Home
programme.sub-title: A Nursing Home Where Hearts Connect
programme.desc: We meet two Nepalese who settled down in Kyushu. Saroj Chaudhary is the director of an elderly care facility in Itoshima, Fukuoka, and Ghale Mankala attends guests at an inn in Yufuin Onsen, Oita.

programme.title: Time-lapse Japan
programme.sub-title: HAGI: The Citrus That Saved the Samurai
programme.desc: *First broadcast on January 19, 2026 As the samurai age ended, citrus production provided a way forward for former warriors in Hagi. Locals still love century-old sweets made using the aromatic skin. Watch them being made in time-lapse.

programme.title: Time-lapse Japan
programme.desc: The Jomon period dates roughly from 13,000 BC to 300 BC. We examine various aspects of Jomon society, with footage from time-lapse creator Shimizu Daisuke. This time: Lacquer.

programme.title: BOSAI: Science that Can Save Your Life
programme.desc: Find out about Japan's emergency food options that meet the needs of various people. Also discover the rolling stock method, a smart way to stockpile emergency food.

programme.title: Activate Your Japanese!
programme.desc: Drama "Xuan Tackles Japan!" It is the day of the summer festival, and they find out that the MC for the karaoke contest is unable to come. Tadokoro asks Xuan to stand in, along with Sasaki. The man who was supposed to be the MC explains what they should do and in what order over the phone, but Sasaki is left confused. Xuan tries to clarify his explanation but is unsuccessful. Yansu appears and gives her advice. How can she make it easier to understand what they should be doing? "Onomatopoeia" -Share Feelings- Texture of Food 2 "Welcome to My Japan!" focuses on the life of NAGATA Marie from the Philippines, who runs a driver's school in Shizuoka Prefecture!

programme.desc: Bara Kyoushitsu in Kani City, Gifu Prefecture, is a preschool designed to eliminate the number of foreign children who stop attending school because they don't understand Japanese.

programme.title: Seasoning the Seasons
programme.desc: Nara, one of Japan's ancient capitals, is home to spirits and demons. Due to its long history, the city has seen its fair share of wars and plagues. For local people the essence of difficulty and disaster is captured in demon form. But demons, with their huge flaming torches, can also help see in the blessings of spring. Demons and fire visit the people of Nara as they pray for a bountiful spring season.

programme.sub-title: Friendship Forged by Shared Atomic Bomb Past
programme.desc: Ari Beser's grandfather served on the planes that dropped atomic bombs on Hiroshima and Nagasaki. Harada Kosuzu's grandfather survived both. Now they are fighting for a world without nuclear weapons. NHK Hiroshima's website (in Japanese) https://www.nhk.or.jp/hiroshima/hibaku/80/

programme.title: National Parks of Japan
programme.desc: Keramashoto National Park comprises more than 30 islands and is known for its highly transparent waters called the Kerama Blue and its coral population. The coral, which supports a thriving marine ecosystem, is protected from predators by local volunteers. The region also boasts a unique culture from its past as the Ryukyu Kingdom.

programme.title: The Seasons of Yamato
programme.desc: Hannyaji Temple is known as "Kosumosudera (cosmos flower temple)." During wintertime, the main flowers are daffodils. They bloom as if they are competing around the stone statues of Buddhists, which were dedicated in appreciation for curing diseases. Are those flowers praising the virtues of the Buddha or showing off their beauty? The 13-story stone pagoda, which has stood there since the Kamakura period, is towering against the crisp blue winter sky. *According to the 24 Solar Terms of Reiwa 4 (2022), Shoukan is from January 5 to 20.

programme.title: Ukiyoe EDO-LIFE
programme.desc: Edo was a city of waterways. The Yoroi Ferry transported people across the Nihonbashi River, one of its main commercial arteries. programme.title: Little Charo
programme.desc: This program is an animation series about a Japanese dog, Charo. He meets and is helped by many mythical creatures of Northern Japan as he searches for eight star talismans.

programme.title: Japanology Plus mini
programme.desc: The cardboard beds used during the Tokyo 2020 Olympic and Paralympic Games captured global attention. That was just one example of the many innovative ways in which Japan has made use of this humble material. Modern cardboard can be insect-repellent, waterproof or strong enough to carry a piano. It's also used in emergency goods such as rooms and toilets. In fact, people in Japan use roughly 150 new cardboard boxes a year. In a 5-minute digest, we examine a broad range of cardboard products.

programme.title: A Cat's-Eye View of Japan
programme.desc: A scallop fisherman's cat, Miya, keeps watch while her owner is at sea. Once he's back, Miya's ready to cuddle. Meanwhile, a cat in Hachinohe City sits on her owner's newspaper to get his attention.

programme.title: NHK NEWSLINE
programme.desc: NHK NEWSLINE brings you up to date with the latest from Japan, Asia and around the world. Our team covers breaking news and major developments, with trusted anchors to tie it all together.

programme.title: ANIME MANGA EXPLOSION
programme.desc: In this episode, we explore the craft of anime sound. Voice actor Otsuka Akio, who has performed in over 400 anime titles, recreates recording sessions from My Hero Academia and BLEACH: Thousand-Year Blood War, revealing the techniques behind iconic lines. We also go behind the scenes at the music recording session for the new anime Star Wars: Visions Volume 3 "The Duel: Payback," where composer Inai Keiji crafts a dramatic score that brings the visuals to life.

programme.title: The New Adventures of Rockie and Her Friends
programme.desc: Rockie is paired up with Juras for a play to put on during the school arts day. When Juras fails to learn the script, Rockie shows frustration, and Juras stops coming to school. Educational theme: Justice and fairness.

programme.desc: NHK NEWSLINE brings you up to date with the latest from Japan, Asia and around the world. Our team covers breaking news and major developments, with trusted anchors to tie it all together.

programme.title: The World Heritage Sites in Japan
programme.sub-title: Triangular Roofs Bring People Together: Historic Villages of Shirakawa-go and Gokayama
programme.desc: Shirakawa-go in Gifu Prefecture is one of Japan's snowiest regions. It's famous for its traditional thatched-roof Gassho-style homes. The triangular roofs distribute the weight of heavy snow evenly, and the steep slopes allow residents to remove snow with little effort. Hearth fires provide heat that dries out thatch and soot that blackens pillars and beams. These homes have lasted for so long because they are still inhabited. The cooperative bond between residents is a key part of life here and is essential when rethatching these homes. Come and visit a mountain village that appears to be frozen in time.

programme.title: Time-lapse Japan
programme.desc: Okinawa Prefecture is a group of subtropical islands in the far south of Japan. We examine its past and present, with footage from time-lapse creator Shimizu Daisuke. This time: The Holiest Place.

programme.title: GRAND SUMO Highlights
programme.desc: NHK WORLD-JAPAN presents a sumo highlights program for fans around the globe. Today the show features all top-division bouts from January 17, Day 7 of the Grand Sumo Tournament in Tokyo.

programme.title: Sumopedia
programme.desc: Sumopedia enriches your sumo experience with information on the techniques, traditions and famous wrestlers of the past. The rules may be simple but there is a lot more to sumo than meets the eye.

programme.desc: NHK NEWSLINE brings you up to date with the latest from Japan, Asia and around the world. Our team covers breaking news and major developments, with trusted anchors to tie it all together.

programme.title: EKIBEN JAPAN
programme.sub-title: Carrying On the Aroma of Yuzu
programme.desc: An ekiben with specialty yuzu from Umaji Village is available beside a tourist railway in Kochi. Yuzu once saved the village from extinction. This is the story of people behind yuzu fragrant ekiben.

programme.title: Core Kyoto
programme.sub-title: Core Kyoto mini Furniture Restoration: Giving Life to Treasured Heirlooms
programme.desc: The furniture cleaning industry is sustained by many Kyotoites' desire to cherish and hand down their belongings over generations. The techniques used to restore paulownia-wood chests, which are used for kimono, to their former glory has been handed down over 3 generations. Discover Kyotoites' respect for history and continuity.

programme.title: Easy Japanese for Work
programme.sub-title: #2 How to politely ask someone to repeat something
programme.desc: This episode is about asking someone to repeat something. Putri-san, from Indonesia, learned Japanese in university. She has been working in the real estate field for 4 years in Japan. Putri-san works entirely in Japanese, but finds some katakana words difficult. By role-playing and receiving guidance from experts, she'll learn how to politely ask someone to repeat something.

programme.title: Zero Waste Life
programme.desc: Artisan Matoba Kensho restores traditional dolls. Beyond cleaning, he repairs damage to faces. Well-cared-for dolls can last 100 years, so he hopes people bring them to him, and never discard them.
